Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Roll-to-Roll Manufacturing of Highly Crystalline Thin Film Semiconductor Substrates for Flexible Electronics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to further the development of a patent pending technology aimed at producing flexible, lightweight, and low-cost semiconductor substrates. These flexible semiconductor films represent the next evolution of the silicon wafer, the foundation of over 90% of today's electronic devices, including computer chips, solar panels, microelectronics, and a wide range of sensors and similar 'internet of things' devices. The silicon wafer, in its current form, is essentially unchanged since its inception over 60 years ago. These wafers, although larger today, remain thick, rigid, fragile, and are limited to circular forms no larger than 450 millimeters (18 inches) in diameter. The ability to produce large-area, high-throughput quantities of this material, in a flexible, more durable format would be truly disruptive, and help to usher in the next generation of affordable, flexible, and pervasive electronic devices. Accelerating the commercialization of this 'wafer 2.0' will help to shape America's high-tech semiconductor manufacturing industry for the 21st century.

The proposed project will focus on the development of this innovative technology at a simulated roll-to-roll prototyping scale, to enhance film crystal quality, repeatability, and electronic properties, while preparing the process for integration into large scale manufacturing. To date, no techniques exist that can produce large-area, highly crystalline silicon or other semiconductor films, that are suitable for high-throughput manufacturing. The technique in this proposed work is a novel, patent pending process, suitable for high-throughput roll-to-roll manufacturing and has several technical advantages that favor high-uniformity crystallization. Low-cost, flexible, wafer-like substrates will open the door for a wide range of electronic devices and fully integrated system-on-chip designs, including sensors, displays, lighting, processors, memory, microelectronics, and photovoltaics. Specific research activities will include optimization of the crystallization process via exploration of operating parameters; improvements and refinements to the prototype chamber equipment; evaluation of intermediate thin-film layers to provide ideal electronic properties and to promote more favorable recrystallization; and, finally, characterization of the resulting semiconductor films using state of the art semiconductor tools at the world's largest nanotechnology focused institute.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lux Semiconductors has completed its National Science Foundation (NSF) Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project. The scope of work undertaken during this award was focused on the development and optimization of Lux's patent pending thin-film silicon recrystallization technology. This novel technology is designed to produce thin sheets of crystalline silicon on ultra-thin, flexible metal foil. Just as the silicon wafer currently serves as the backbone for nearly all modern integrated electronics, the successful development of Lux's technology could lead to a next generation wafer alternative that is lower cost, flexible, and suitable for high throughput roll-to-roll manufacturing. The commercial deployment of such a platform is anticipated to have wide ranging implications for a number of emerging electronics markets, including wearables for health and fitness, micro displays for augmented and virtual reality, and multifunctional wireless sensors for the Internet of Things (IoT).

As a result of this NSF sponsored work, Lux was able to significantly improve key aspects of its core process technology. Key system upgrades were made to Lux's novel recrystallization chamber to expand system capabilities and incorporate more sophisticated process controls. High quality thin-film depositions were performed by Lux and its partners to provide sample material used for process optimization. Samples were processed in Lux's custom-built recrystallization chamber and analyzed by state-of-the-art characterization equipment. A notable result of this iterative optimization effort was a significant improvement to the surface roughness and uniformity of the thin-film silicon. These characteristics in particular are critical to advancing the material towards a suitability for fabrication of integrated circuits, used in flexible electronics.

Subsequent efforts that expand on this NSF work will look to qualify Lux's films for both conventional integrated circuit fabrication and emerging printed electronics techniques. Qualification will be accomplished, in part, through the fabrication and testing of fundamental elements that form the basic building blocks of integrated circuits, including transistors, diodes, resistors, and capacitors.

This work represents an important and significant step towards the development of flexible crystalline silicon substrates that may lead to a next generation material platform for integrated electronics. Through extensive customer engagement efforts conducted during the performance of this award, Lux has received tangible commercial interest to support this possibility. With an eye towards commercialization, Lux looks forward to building on the success of this NSF SBIR Phase I project and continuing to execute on its technology development roadmap.
